review_title: Nice people but need better on-boarding and pay
pros: Nice campus, staff, and facilities. It's a good university and the graduates put out are at a high standard. I was given a lot of autonomy to teach whatever way I thought best.
cons: Software infrastructure is outdated, pay is too low for lower union staff, and on-boarding was basically non-existant.

review_title: Would recommend to anyone interested in learning more about participatory design research.
pros: Working as a research assistant gives you real-life experience on a very part-time basis. This is great for when you're still wanting to enroll in classes full-time.
cons: It can be tough to manage both your academic and professional workload.

review_title: Okay part time job for a student

pros: Laid back job, coworkers were mostly friendly
cons: Low pay, gets a bit boring especially on slow days

review_title: Great design pedagogy, but low salary
pros: The schools teaching and process is very research and theory heavy which is great if that is what you like. The school really want to grow into something great but isn't there yet. Generally most teachers are passionate about what they do.
cons: Very low pay compared to other Universities in the region as it used to be a college/institute. the admin definitely has lots of growing pains as they expand and move to their new campus.

pros: Outstanding colleagues. Extraordinary students. Very good health benefits. Wonderful art gallery, fantastic Aboriginal Gathering Place, excellent book shop and innovative press.
cons: Faculty resourcing is very limited with and there is a growing resource focus on the expansion of Administration and facilities.

limited career opportunities within the institute

review_title: Low Faculty Morale & Pay, Insane Teaching Load
pros: Faculty colleagues are generally a joy to work with.
cons:
Emily Carr has one of the highest faculty workloads of any university in the country. Faculty teach about twice as many courses compared to a standard university. The teaching load at Emily Carr is 10 studio courses per year or 8 lecture courses per year. Most universities have a teaching load of 4 or 5 courses.

The faculty are scared enough of the administration that they avoid using their work email addresses to discuss any labour-related items because they are afraid of managerial surveillance and retaliation. Faculty do not feel listened to or empowered by the administration. 

Pay for faculty is low enough that most faculty find it impossible to survive in Vancouver without the help of a partner's/spouse's income. Faculty pay scales are dormant for long term employees. There is little room for incremental pay raises over time for faculty. The faculty do not socially hang out with each other. They are too burnt out.

Although there was considerable promise with the new president  (Sidall) the institution has been unsuccessful in maintaining operating funds and is currently several million dollars short. Management typically operates in "putting fires out" panic mode due to lack of resources, focus and strategy.

The university has spent all of its money on a building. Investment in faculty has never been a priority. Faculty are treated as disposable.

I accepted a faculty job at Emily Carr instead of a competing offer from a different school. I was attracted by the art school energy and Vancouver  and thought my teaching load wouldn't matter. What a bad mistake.

review_title: Great place to work, but unstable and political
pros: Great colleagues and students. Fascinating projects. Feels like you are really contributing to something greater.
cons: Lots of Faculty are old and scared of change. Students crave technical support that is unavailable. Fragmented web presence, both internally and externally.
